B.Sc. Nursing Syllabus

Official Four-Year Program Curriculum as per the Indian Nursing Council (INC).

Program Overview

The B.Sc. Nursing degree is a four-year, eight-semester program designed to prepare students as qualified registered nurses for diverse healthcare settings. The curriculum is competency-based, integrating mastery and self-directed learning to develop critical thinking, clinical skills, and professional values.

Philosophy

The Indian Nursing Council believes that health is a fundamental right. Nursing is a profession that utilizes knowledge from arts and sciences to provide holistic care. The program prepares graduates to be exemplary citizens who can provide promotive, preventive, curative, and rehabilitative care, responding to national health aspirations.

Aims

  • To produce knowledgeable, competent nurses with critical thinking skills.
  • To prepare graduates for professional roles in various healthcare settings.
  • To empower nurses to make independent decisions and conduct evidence-based practice.
  • To prepare nurses for roles as practitioners, teachers, supervisors, and managers.

Core Competencies

Graduates will be proficient in ten core areas, including Patient-Centered Care, Professionalism, Leadership, Communication, Teamwork, Safety, Quality Improvement, and Evidence-Based Practice.

The Indian Nursing Council sets forth detailed guidelines for any organization wishing to establish a B.Sc. Nursing college. This includes requirements for the parent trust/society, a 100-bedded parent hospital, and obtaining an Essentiality Certificate from the State Government. The guidelines also cover physical facilities (teaching and hostel blocks), clinical facilities, and staffing patterns to ensure a high standard of education.

Course Structure (8 Semesters)

The B.Sc. Nursing program is structured across eight semesters, with a combination of foundational, core, and elective courses. The total program includes over 6600 hours of theory, lab, and clinical practice.

Semester Subjects Total Hours
I Semester General Science, Communicative English, Applied Anatomy & Physiology, Applied Sociology & Psychology, Nursing Foundations I 760
II Semester Applied Biochemistry, Applied Nutrition & Dietetics, Nursing Foundations II (incl. First Aid), Intro to Community Health Nursing 780
III Semester Applied Microbiology & Infection Control, Pharmacology I, Pathology I, Adult Health Nursing I, Professionalism & Ethics 800
IV Semester Pharmacology II, Pathology II & Genetics, Adult Health Nursing II (incl. Geriatric), Educational Technology 800
V Semester Child Health Nursing I, Mental Health Nursing I, Nursing Management & Leadership, Nursing Research & Statistics, Health Informatics, Forensic Nursing 790
VI Semester Child Health Nursing II, Mental Health Nursing II, Community Health Nursing I, Midwifery/OBG Nursing I 800
VII Semester Community Health Nursing II, Midwifery/OBG Nursing II 820
VIII Semester Internship (Community, Adult, Child, Mental Health, Midwifery) 1056

Mandatory & Elective Modules

The curriculum includes mandatory modules like First Aid, Basic Cardiac Life Support (BCLS), and Skilled Birth Attendant (SBA). Students must also complete four elective modules from a wide range of topics such as Palliative Care, Disaster Management, Stress Management, and more.

Examination Scheme

Assessment is conducted through a combination of internal assessments and end-semester university examinations. The minimum pass mark for nursing courses is 50% (C Grade), while for English and electives, it is 40% (P Grade).

Exams cover subjects like Applied Anatomy & Physiology, Nursing Foundations, and Applied Nutrition. Internal marks from the first semester are combined with the second semester for a comprehensive assessment.

Subjects include Adult Health Nursing, Pharmacology, Pathology, and Educational Technology. The university exam for combined subjects like Pharmacology & Pathology is held at the end of the fourth semester.

Covers major clinical subjects like Child Health Nursing, Mental Health Nursing, and the first parts of Community Health and Midwifery Nursing.

The final university theory exams cover Community Health Nursing II and Midwifery/OBG Nursing II. The eighth semester is an internship with a final competency assessment.

Key Examination Regulations

  • A candidate must pass in theory and practical exams separately for each paper.
  • All previous examinations must be cleared before appearing for the fifth-semester examination, and again before the seventh semester.
  • The maximum period to complete the course successfully is 8 years.
  • Practical examinations are conducted jointly by one internal and one external examiner.

Admission & Regulations

Admission Terms and Conditions

  • Age: Minimum 17 years on Dec 31st of the admission year. Maximum age is 35 years.
  • Educational Qualification: Passed 12th Standard (10+2) with a minimum of 45% marks in core/elective subjects (Science/Arts/Humanities/Commerce) and passed English individually. For SC/ST/OBC candidates, the minimum mark is 40%.
  • Admission Process: Admission is through an entrance examination conducted by the University/State Government.
  • Medical Fitness: Candidates must be medically fit.

Reservation Policy

Reservation for SC/ST/OBC/PH/EWS candidates is subject to the policies of the Central/State Government. A 3% disability reservation is considered for candidates with 40-50% locomotor disability of the lower extremity.

Grading System

A 10-point grading system is used, where 'C' Grade (50-59.99%) is the minimum passing grade for nursing courses.

Letter GradeGrade PointPercentage of Marks
O (Outstanding)10100%
A+ (Excellent)990-99.99%
A (Very Good)880-89.99%
B+ (Good)770-79.99%
B (Above Average)660-69.99%
C (Average/Pass)550-59.99%
P (Pass - English Only)440-49.99%
F (Fail)0Below Pass Mark
